abstract: An increasingly popular set of techniques adopted by software engineering (SE) researchers to automate development tasks are those rooted in the concept Deep Learning (DL). title: Machine/Deep Learning for Software Engineering: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Simin Wang; LiGuo Huang; Amiao Gao; Jidong Ge; Tengfei Zhang; Haitao Feng; Ishna Satyarth; Ming Li; He Zhang; Vincent Ng
keywords: Generalizability theory; Interpretability; Computer science; Artificial intelligence; Machine learning
abstract: Since 2009, the deep learning revolution, which was triggered by introduction of ImageNet, has stimulated synergy between Software Engineering (SE) and Machine Learning (ML)/Deep (DL). Meanwhile, critical reviews have emerged that suggest ML/DL should be used cautiously. To improve applicability generalizability ML/DL-related SE studies, we conducted a 12-year Systematic Literature Review (SLR) on 1,428 papers published 2009 2020. Our trend analysis demonstrated impacts brought to SE. We examined complexity applying solutions problems how such led issues concerning reproducibility replicability studies in Specifically, investigated ML DL differ data preprocessing, model training, evaluation when applied tasks, what details need provided ensure study can reproduced or replicated. By categorizing rationales behind selection techniques into five themes, analyzed performance, robustness, interpretability, complexity, simplicity affected choices models.

title: Machine Learning-Based Software Defect Prediction for Mobile Applications: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Manzura Jorayeva; Akhan Akbulut; Cagatay Catal; Alok Mishra
keywords: Machine learning; Artificial intelligence; Computer science; Artificial neural network; Deep learning
abstract: Software defect prediction studies aim to predict defect-prone components before the testing stage of software development process. The main benefit these models is that more resources can be allocated fault-prone modules effectively. While a few have been developed for mobile applications, systematic overview still missing. Therefore, we carried out Systematic Literature Review (SLR) study evaluate how machine learning has applied faults in applications. This defined nine research questions, and 47 relevant were selected from scientific databases respond questions. Results show most focused on Android applications (i.e., 48%), supervised 92%), object-oriented metrics mainly preferred. top five preferred algorithms are Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machines, Logistic Regression, Artificial Neural Networks, Decision Trees. Researchers mostly Object-Oriented metrics. Only deep including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Deep Belief Networks (DBN), (DNN). first systematically reviews It will pave way further fault help both researchers practitioners this field.
